sentences.sentence: By Andrea Mrozek, Peter Jon Mitchell and Brian DijkemaPoliticians are all the same, you say?
Well, that's actually not true - at least in the case of childcare.
Almost from the moment the parties put their political machines into high gear, the election campaign has turned into a real debate (a referendum?)

on two very contrasting views on childcare.And it's about time we hashed out the policy issue.The Liberals entered the campaign with the promise of $10-a-day licensed childcare spaces and a handful of signed federal-provincial agreements to help make that happen.In essence, the plan favours only one type of childcare.

You use it or lose it.The Conservatives take a different approach: "cash for parents" in the form of a tax credit for childcare expenses.The central idea is to empower families to choose the kind of paid, non-parental childcare that suits their needs best.Cardus has long advocated putting parents in the driver's seat on childcare(https://www.cardus.ca/themes/child-care/).

So, it's heartening to see a genuine and healthy debate on whether funding should go to one type of care provider or to families themselves to choose from a variety of care options.But let's not stop at two policy options.

There are at least two other factors for Canadians to consider regarding federal involvement in the provincial jurisdiction of childcare.First, which policy helps the greatest number of people?Canadian families use diverse forms of childcare to meet their needs.

Pre-pandemic Statistics Canada data suggests that among all children under age six, 32 per cent were in centres and pre-schools, 15 per cent were cared for by a relative other than a parent, and 12 per cent were in a family childcare home.

Still others had outside caregivers in the home, attended afterschool care or were not in care at all.Funding one type of care ignores the diverse arrangements families use, including licensed and un-licensed, public and private childcare arrangements.
Leaders should respect the roles of mothers, fathers, grandparents, extended family, or any other person of the primary caregiver's choice.

Childcare is the care of a child no matter who provides that care.Barbara Kay: One-size-fits-all solutions won't work for childcare, especially after the pandemic(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/barbara-kay-one-size-fits-all-solutions-wont-work-for-childcare-especially-after-the-pandemic)Tasha Kheiriddin: Liberals' 'national childcare' plan serves unions and business interests, not parents(https://nationalpost.com/news/tasha-kheiriddin-liberals-national-childcare-plan-serves-unions-and-business-interests-not-parents)Leaders should also acknowledge that about 40 per cent children under six are in parental care only, according to Statistics Canada(https://www.cardus.ca/research/family/reports/child-care-by-the-numbers-canada/).
Some parents are on parental leave and many others choose not to use outside care.
Less than three per cent of Canadian children under the age of six are in parental care because there were no other options.

Fair and flexible policy includes these families, too (which no party's policy currently does).Secondly, childcare is a family policy that should prioritize the well-being of children.Somehow, the campaign has already lost the handle and framed childcare as primarily an economic policy.

All the major parties, Liberal, Conservative, and NDP, have sung largely from the same song sheet on this, arguing that childcare funding is essential to economic recovery and for growing the GDP.Despite the focus on the economy, labour force participation and the GDP, parents aren't thinking about these things when they consider how best to meet their care needs.
Child well-being is parents' first concern.

Childcare policy should, first and foremost, free parents to make decisions regarding children's care.Let's remember that early in the pandemic, there was a reasonable concern the health crisis would create a childcare supply crunch.

It hasn't been easy for providers but with the help of emergency aid over 90 per cent of providers were back up and running in many provinces by the fall of 2020.A national survey(https://www.cardus.ca/news/news-releases/families-finding-childcare-solutions-despite-pandemic-disruptions/) in the spring of 2021 found that most parents had returned to their previous arrangement or found new arrangements.
The good news is that childcare supply has largely survived the pandemic to this point.The campaign debate should focus on the most equitable way to help families navigate their needs.
We should ask how these policies can help families achieve the stable, healthy family life they desire.So, yes, the childcare debate in Canada is off to a good start.
But let's take it further and deeper.There are real choices to be made in childcare.

An election campaign is a great time to debate them.Andrea Mrozek, Peter Jon Mitchell and Brian Dijkema co-authored Look Before You Leap: The Real Costs and Complexities of National Daycare(https://www.cardus.ca/research/family/reports/look-before-you-leap/) for think-tank Cardus.
